questions.text: A patient on Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) comes with pruritus, eczema, and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals a subepidermal blister. The direct Immunofluorescence of the lesions showed Linear C3 and IgG on the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid In bullous pemphigoid, itchy eczematous lesions can be seen. The associated antibody is IgG. Direct immunofluorescence linear deposition shows IgG and C3.

Highyeild:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) is the most common autoimmune subepidermal blistering disorder Characteristically presents with tense bullae and intense generalized pruritus. Spongiosis and superficial papillary dermal infiltrate of eosinophils without vesiculation are characteristic features of urticarial lesions and direct immunofluorescence will highlight the autoantibodies against the basement membrane zone Etiology Autoantibodies against proteins arranged at the dermal-epidermal junction (Autoantibodies against 2 parts of the basal keratinocyte hemidesmosomal proteins BP antigen 230 (BPAG1) and BP antigen 180 (BPAG2 or type XVII collagen) Drug-induced bullous pemphigoid. Eg : furosemide and spironolactone, NSAIDs, amoxicillin, PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors, gliptins, and TNF alpha inhibitors Note : Unlike pemphigus vulgaris, the Nikolsky sign is negative in typical cases of bullous pemphigoid Treatment : Systemic corticosteroids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A: Pemphigus vulgaris is an intraepidermal immunobullous disease. They present with flaccid blisters. OPTION B : Pemphigus foliaceus is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the development of blisters and erosions on the skin, primarily on the upper body and face. There is lack of mucosal involvement Option D : Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy and blistering skin lesions. It is actually associated with an autoimmune response to gluten. A skin biopsy from a lesion near the affected area is examined to detect specific immunoglobulin A (IgA) deposits under the skin

questions.text: A 24 years old young male presented with asymptomatic scaly lesions over back, symmetrical in distribution. Images of the lesions are given, identify the disease and the pattern of lesions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Christmas tree, collarette,pityriasis rosea Pityriasis Rosea is a scaly red lesion that usually occurs on the trunk. They are scaly herald patches and a collarette of scales can be seen.

Highyeild:

Pityriasis rosea is clinically characterized by a herald patch or mother patch followed by scaly oval plaques on the trunk and proximal extremities along the Langer’s lines of cleavage giving characteristic “Christmas-tree” appearance. Pityriasis rosea typically starts with a single, larger patch called the “herald patch” or “mother patch. Causes of pityriasis rosea : Suspected as related to viral infections, possibly involving human herpesvirus 6 or human herpesvirus 7 Pityriasis rosea is generally self-limiting and does not require specific treatment.Over-the-counter antihistamines or topical corticosteroids may be recommended to manage itching and discomfort.
